pros: Library staff friendly and helpful.  Machinists and technical staff also friendly, helpful, and good at what they do- very important for doing engineering research.  Other engineering/science departments were happy to share access to equipment.  Several new engineering buildings have gone up, so there is lots of good lab space available.  Generous retirement saving plan: 9% of your pay, starting after 18 months of service.
cons: Well, I can't really think of any.  I had a great experience at TU.  I worked with good faculty and students, I was paid well and treated as a peer by the professors I worked with/for.  I suppose this might be the con- my good experience within one department is no guarantee that your experience with other faculty will be equivalent.  Meet the faculty and make sure you like them before you sign on!

review_title: Don't judge book by its cover
pros: Good people, smart students, good benefits, beautiful campus
cons: Aloof administrators. very slow raise in salary process unless a athletic coach or in the ivory tower. Do well at job task and more added on you. Pay scale not equal to same job in corporate, but less stress in higher edu.

pros: Working as a research assistant, while pursuing my PhD. I would really recommend the University of Tulsa. The faculty is friendly and accessible and my coworkers are great! We all have a very professional work environment, but the people here make everything feel lighter and more enjoyable.
cons: Depending on which department you are, the stipend is somewhat below the national average. Also, living in Tulsa requires you to have a car.

review_title: It has been a wonderful experience.
pros: Friendly people, strong financial resources, and a beautiful campus are three primary reasons to come here to work.  Based on informal conversations with others in academe, it is hard to beat TU as a workplace.
cons: Seniority often counts for more than merit here.  Some of the leadership has been around for decades, and it is difficult to change processes because of organizational inertia.

pros: Most people come to work for TU to get the tuition benefit for their immediate family members.  You can't beat being able to send your children to the best college in Oklahoma for free.
cons: Pay is not good.  That is the reason most people leave after their children graduate.

pros: I loved my job at TU! I enjoyed working with the students and university.  The smallest Division I campus in the USA is very welcoming. This is a great place to get your education.  The small campus is easy to navigate.
cons: Unfortunately, the board and trustees of TU have made a number of poor business decisions. These would include the acquisition of the "black hole" of Gilcrease Museum, a questionable partnership between the university and the City of Tulsa. Schools make their money off of their students, not museum patrons.

pros: Great salary, Great benefits, Plenty of vacation / Holiday, Tuition waive for employees and their dependents,  Decent retirement benefit.
cons:
The administration is corrupt. They will protect the company at all costs. This includes covering up for harassment, unethical practices, and in some cases,  criminal activity among the upper echelon.  This is accomplished by eliminating anyone who complains makes a complaint to HR or won't carry out an unethical act. 

Some examples of unethical activity  include:
Ordering supervisors to falsify performance reviews, falsify reports, falsify dates on official documents, lie to employees, treat certain employees with extreme prejudiced or favoritism.
Some other examples are:
Sexually harassment, intimidation of witnesses, fabrication of evidence, coercion, destruction of evidence.

review_title: Great Job, Salary, Benefits, but let me do my job.
pros:
The company offers excellent pay even for entry level security officers, (well more than others in the city). The insurance (blue cross-blue shield) covers your entire family if elected and the company pays half the premium! 

Any full time employee qualifies for their tuition benefit (free tuition for one degree!), which covers the employee and dependents, such as wife and children. The tuition benefit extends to other select universities under a benefit called tuition exchange, which allows for an employee or dependent to attend another (specified) university.

As an assistant supervisor (corporal) there is an immediate bump in pay to about 5% above a top level officer and as a supervisor (currently) jumps to about 20 per hour with step raises until you cap out after 4 years, and yearly cost of living increases (about 2%). 

After 2 years the company pays in (approximately  9% of your salary) toward your retirement, even if you elect not to add additional funds.  

Overall, the salary and benefits among the best in the area. All full time employees get great discounts on software from the university.
cons:
There are plenty of Cons: These are limited to the common complaints of the employees. 

Favoritism is to be rampant. suggestions by the less favored ones are ignored while the same suggestions by those in friendship with administration are not. Select employees are permitted to violate policy, and at times be verbally abusive to subordinates, while complaints against such are not kept confidential and will result in excessive scrutiny and other "disciplinary" actions.

The upper administration does not care if you get injured. There have been several employees injured as the result of "mandatory training" that employees were forced to take part in. Of these, two requested to be excused from training due to previous injuries, but requests were denied.

(Most) Employees are required to take part in a physical agility test consisting of 1.5 mile run, 20 sit-ups and 18 push-ups every 6 months, In and of itself the test is not that difficult, but it is scheduled during the hottest and coldest parts of the year, and some employees are allowed to ride a bike rather than run. This is done on a "Case by case basis" as overseen by top level administration. (More Favoritism) Furthermore, the policy specifically states that the test will be performed once per year, not every 6 months. 

Under some supervision, officers are excessively micro managed beyond any reasonable expectation. Under this particular circumstance, there is no standard of expectation. The expectation is that you will never do anything correctly without supervisory input.  

Due to the above, there is a very high turnover. Few are employed for more than 1-2 years.

pros:
*A Relaxed environment with somewhat casual dress code
*You are encouraged to learn and expand your knowledge
cons:
*End user (Faculty) are pushy about receiving special treatment.
*Low pay compared to other higher education institutions in Oklahoma and especially compared to general private sector work.
*Poor health care coverage that constantly receives cuts/price increases.

cons: Pay isn't on par with other larger universities due to the outrageous tuition. Although tuition is covered, a larger monthly stipend would be greatly appreciated.

pros: If you are a first-year PhD student, you are most likely to receive teaching assistant. Because the class size is quite small, so the grading job is easy to handle.
cons: Department is also very small. Opportunities such as presenting works at international conferences are rare. And if you are learning something like physics, it is quite hard to find jobs on market.

pros: Super diverse community dedicated to research. Flexible hours. Vacation, sick pay, and holidays accumulate to about a month of paid time off. Always working with leading edge technology.
cons: Crazy hours during testing. A lot of sensitive students who don't like to get their feelings hurt.

review_title: Great benefits but management in certain departments can be slow to move, making the job frustrating at times.

cons: Below market salaries for staff can be disheartening, and slow to move management can be frustrating. As with every company there are some incompetent folks

review_title: Very supportive, helpful and a great place to work
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tulsa, OK
pros:
- Take care of their students and provides all the necessary supports and help.
- Professors are highly supportive and take care of their students.
- Co-workers are very supportive and helpful.
- Lots of helpful events and resources are available for help.
- University President himself take care a lot of all the students and communities.
cons: -Management can think to increase remuneration by year.

pros: Getting to work with your peers and having flexible-ish hours really make the research experience fun and enjoyable. Not to mention all of the hands-on learning you get to do that you wouldn't get in the classroom otherwise.
cons: You have to be self motivated to make progress on your research. Not really a con as more of a warning for those who are not self motivating.

pros: Great working environment, awesome staff, and opportunities for student leaders to assume a role of responsibility.
cons: Don't expect an easy job, you will need to plan many activities, keep in constant contact with residents, and continue to grow in this position.

pros: My department is great. Most of the staff at the university are very helpful. It is also very well respected within the community. Also, as a grad assistant they pay 100% for your insurance.
cons: The pay is horrible, but that's to be expected as a graduate student I suppose. The students you end up teaching tend to come from very conservative backgrounds, however.

review_title: Worst job in my entire life
pros: Would have paid my child's tuition for school if the work environment would not have been not simply toxic, but criminal.
cons: Nearly the entire housekeeping and maintenance dept is run by people who protect their territory, act like junior mafia with intimidation practices, and must doing something illegal to act in this way.  They spend all their time  not working, doing a terrible job, and then then excusing themselves with complaints of being short handed (when they actually come to work-- some of them clock in for each other on a non-monitored clock so they can take a couple of days a week off every week.)  They have full access to a fleet of commercial white vans which they drive around all day doing who knows what.  There appears to be no accountability on the drive miles.  The "Leads" are the fox guarding the henhouse so again no accountability on work actually being done. They don't care about the multi-million dollar buildings.  They do NOT care about the students and will do petty things like lock the students' kitchens to punish them for something that didn't get cleaned.  Because then they have to actually clean something.  When it was clear that I was different and had a work ethic I was shunned (given the silent treatment) and even intimidated by being corned in small dark closets by 4 male maintenance guys.  On 4 occasions on the same day and even followed in my car, a couple of times chased around my neighborhood at high speed.  My husband had to come out of the house with a shotgun to make them leave.  I called the police who suggested I quit.  My boss would not even reply to my text. Unprofessional does not describe the dept.  Criminal is the only word that does.  But what can you do.  TU has trained an army of lawyers  and judges that would prevent any investigation or lawsuit from succeeding.  All this and minimum wage too.

review_title: I have an amazing time doing research as an undergraduate

pros: They offer opportunities for undergraduates to be a part of science. The Physics department is especially well-versed in influencing students to get involved.
